nodes.label: Automated Bone Marrow Cytology System
nodes.summary: An end-to-end deep learning-based system for automated analysis of bone marrow aspirate digital whole slide images, from region detection to cell classification and summarization.

nodes.label: Region of Interest (ROI) Detection
nodes.summary: The first step of the system, which automatically identifies suitable regions for cytological analysis from a large whole slide image (WSI).

nodes.label: Algorithm
nodes.summary: A fine-tuned DenseNet model is employed to rapidly and automatically select appropriate ROI tiles.

nodes.label: Performance Metrics
nodes.summary: The system achieves high accuracy in selecting suitable regions for analysis.

nodes.label: Cell Detection and Classification
nodes.summary: The core component that simultaneously identifies individual bone marrow cells and classifies them into discrete categories within the selected ROIs.

nodes.label: Algorithm
nodes.summary: Utilizes a YOLO (You Only Look Once) model, specifically YOLOV4, trained from scratch to perform object detection and classification in a single step.

nodes.label: Key Feature
nodes.summary: Solves detection and classification simultaneously using a regression approach, increasing computational efficiency compared to methods like R-CNN.

nodes.label: YOLOV4 Optimization
nodes.summary: Optimized for small object detection and uses complete intersection-over-union loss (CIoU) for faster convergence and better accuracy.

nodes.label: Performance Metrics
nodes.summary: Demonstrates strong performance in identifying and categorizing 16 key cellular and non-cellular objects.

nodes.label: Histogram of Cell Types (HCT)
nodes.summary: A novel representation that summarizes the collective cytological information for a patient, acting as a unique cytological fingerprint.

nodes.label: Definition
nodes.summary: A quantitative representation of the class probability distribution of all identified bone marrow cell types.

nodes.label: Purpose
nodes.summary: To capture and summarize complex cytomorphological information, providing a foundation for more efficient and accurate AI-enabled diagnostics in hematology.

nodes.label: AI-based Bone Marrow Cell Differential Counting
nodes.summary: Development and validation of a machine-learning algorithm using a Mask R-CNN model to automate the differential counting of nucleated cells in bone marrow aspiration smears.

nodes.label: Objective
nodes.summary: To develop and validate an artificial intelligence (AI)-based algorithm for identifying and classifying nucleated cells in bone marrow (BM) smears to automate differential counting.

nodes.label: Methodology
nodes.summary: An AI model was trained and validated using a large, multinational dataset of expert-annotated cell images from bone marrow smears.

nodes.label: AI Model Architecture
nodes.summary: A Mask Region-based Convolutional Neural Network (Mask R-CNN) was used to detect and classify individual bone marrow cells.

nodes.label: Training Phase
nodes.summary: The model was trained on a large dataset of expert-annotated images from slides stained with Liu's or Wright-Giemsa stain.

nodes.label: Training Dataset
nodes.summary: Consisted of 542 slides containing 597,222 annotated cells.

nodes.label: Stain Types
nodes.summary: 85.1% of slides were stained with Liu’s stain and 14.9% with Wright–Giemsa stain.

nodes.label: Annotation Process
nodes.summary: Experts from different institutes held consensus meetings to ensure consistent cell classification criteria.

nodes.label: Validation Phase
nodes.summary: The trained AI model's performance was evaluated using a separate, multinational clinical dataset.

nodes.label: Validation Dataset
nodes.summary: A real-world dataset from three centers in Taiwan and one in the United States, comprising 200,639 cells.

nodes.label: Results and Performance
nodes.summary: The AI model demonstrated high accuracy in both testing and validation phases, with strong correlation to manual counting methods.

nodes.label: Testing Performance
nodes.summary: The model achieved an accuracy of 0.94 on the initial testing dataset of 26,170 cells.

nodes.label: Validation Performance
nodes.summary: On the multinational real-world dataset, the model achieved an overall accuracy of 0.881.

nodes.label: Cell-Specific Precision
nodes.summary: High precision was observed for key cell types: Blasts (0.927), Bands and PMNs (0.955), Plasma cells (0.930), and Lymphocytes (0.789).

nodes.label: Correlation with Manual Counting
nodes.summary: A strong correlation (ρ > 0.8) was found between AI and manual differential counting percentages for most cell categories.

nodes.label: Challenges in Development
nodes.summary: The paper highlights significant challenges in data collection and annotation for developing AI models for BM analysis.

nodes.label: Data Collection
nodes.summary: Difficulties include obtaining sufficient high-quality BM samples, especially for rare diseases, and the lack of routine digital imaging in clinical practice.

nodes.label: Data Annotation
nodes.summary: Annotation is time-consuming, requires proficient experts (who are in short supply), and is complicated by inter-institute variations in classification criteria.

nodes.label: Conclusion
nodes.summary: The developed AI algorithm was clinically validated, can simultaneously locate and classify BM cells, and shows potential for automating BM differential counting in clinical settings.
